Detailed Description

The library currently supports streaming 1D-3D datasets that grow along a single dimension (the time dimension). Supported data types are int32 and double. Datasets can be organized in groups. Attributes of types int32, double, string, and vectors of those types can be written.

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum err_t

Error types

Enumerator:
NO_ERROR 

No error.

CREATE_FAPL 

Unable to create file access property list for file.

SET_FAPL_FAMILY 

Unable to set fil ei/o driver to family.

CREATE_FILE 

Unable to create file.

CLOSE_FILE 

Unable to close file.

CREATE_DATASPACE 

Unable to create dataspace.

CREATE_DCPL 

Unable to create dataspace creation property list.

SET_CHUNK_SIZE 

Unable to set chunk size.

SET_FILL_TIME 

Unable to set fill time.

CREATE_DAPL 

Unable to create dataspace access property list.

CHUNK_CACHE_PARAMS 

Unable to set chunk cache parameters.

CREATE_DATASET 

Unable to create dataset.

OPEN_DATASPACE 

Unable to open dataspace.

SET_EXTENT 

Unable to extend dataset.

SELECT_HYPERSLAB 

Unable to select hyperslab.

CREATE_MEMSPACE 

Unable to create memory space.

WRITE_DATA 

Unable to write data.

CREATE_ATTRIBUTE 

Unable to create attribute.

Function Documentation

err_t append_to_dataset_double ( hid_t  dataset_id,
double *  data,
const hsize_t  count 
)

Append data of type double to a dataset. The time dimension is always assumed to be the last dimension.

Parameters:
dataset_idHandle to the dataset the data is appended to.
dataPointer to the actual data.
countNumber of data points to be added. This refers to the last (time) dimension. Thus, if you're extending a 3D dataset that is 5 x 10 x Time data is assumed to be of size 5 x 10 x count.
Returns:
NO_ERROR if successful, an error code otherwise
err_t append_to_dataset_int32 ( hid_t  dataset_id,
int *  data,
const hsize_t  count 
)

Append int32 data to a dataset. The time dimension is always assumed to be the last dimension.

Parameters:
dataset_idHandle to the dataset the data is appended to.
dataPointer to the actual data.
countNumber of data points to be added. This refers to the last (time) dimension. Thus, if you're extending a 3D dataset that is 5 x 10 x Time data is assumed to be of size 5 x 10 x count.
Returns:
NO_ERROR if successful, an error code otherwise

Close HDF5 dataset.

hid_t create_dataset_1d_double ( hid_t  loc_id,
const char *  name,
const hsize_t  chunk,
err_t &  error 
)

Creates a one-dimensional dataset of type double. The content is assumed to be a scalar function of time.

Parameters:
loc_idHandle to HDF5 location (file or group within a file).
nameName of the dataset to be created.
chunkChunk size for time dimension.
errorIf an error occurs, the error code will be written into this variable.
Returns:
Handle to the dataset if successful. Otherwise -1 is returned.
hid_t create_dataset_1d_int32 ( hid_t  loc_id,
const char *  name,
const hsize_t  chunk,
err_t &  error 
)

Creates a one-dimensional dataset of 32 bit integers. The content is assumed to be a scalar function of time.

Parameters:
loc_idHandle to HDF5 location (file or group within a file).
nameName of the dataset to be created.
chunkChunk size for time dimension.
errorIf an error occurs, the error code will be written into this variable.
Returns:
Handle to the dataset if successful. Otherwise -1 is returned.
hid_t create_dataset_2d_double ( hid_t  loc_id,
const char *  name,
const hsize_t  dim1,
const hsize_t *  chunks,
err_t &  error 
)

Creates a two-dimensional dataset of type double. The content is assumed to be a vector-valued function of time (such as an array of electrodes). Time is represented along the second dimension.

Parameters:
loc_idHandle to HDF5 location (file or group within a file).
nameName of the dataset to be created.
dim1Size of first dimension.
chunksChunk sizes.
errorIf an error occurs, the error code will be written into this variable.
Todo:
Fill in recommended chunk sizes above. Probably we want the time dimension to be chunked in the same size as the chunks of data we are writing. For the first dimension, in the case of tetrodes a chunk size of 4 seems useful while for single electrodes a chunk size of 1 is probably best (at least for reading performance since usually a large portion in time is read, which will most of the time create a lot of overhead if only a single channel or tetrode is read).

Creates a three-dimensional dataset of type double. The content is assumed to be a matrix-valued function of time (for instance, a time series of images). Time is represented along the third dimension.

nameName of the dataset to be created.
dim1Size of first dimension.
dim2Size of second dimension.
chunksChunk sizes.
errorIf an error occurs, the error code will be written into this variable.
Returns:
Handle to the dataset if successful. Otherwise -1 is returned.

hid_t create_file ( const char *  name,
err_t *  error 
)

Create HDF5 file using the family driver so it can exceed 2GB on 32 bit systems.

Parameters:
nameName of the file to be created
Returns:
File identifier. A non-negative value if the file was created successfully.
hid_t create_group ( hid_t  loc_id,
const char *  name 
)

Create group within HDF5 file.

Parameters:
loc_idIdentifier of parent for the group to be created. This can be either a file id or another group id.
nameName of the group to be created
Returns:
Group identifier. A non-negative value if the group was created successfully.
